talk.start.para: .)—Today Floraville Public School visited Parliament House. It is a quality school that gives the students who attend it a rounded education. Floraville is a school that believes in instilling values in the children that attend it. It instils in all students a love of the environment, of sport, of learning and of Australia. On Friday, 23 July, I attended Floraville school's National Tree Day activities. It was a culmination of several years of wishing, planning, consulting and collaborating with the community and the students. More than 600 volunteers planted over 600 plants, including nearly 500 grasses and 135 trees. Over 500 students, their teachers, parents, grandparents—and, yes, me too—were all involved in this project. I was given special permission to plant three trees as all the other trees were planted by the students.

speech.para: The focal point of the area that was being restored was the frog pond, because it is a frog pond reserve. It is a habitat area that was previously a waste area. It had been overgrown with kikuyu, bitou bush and lantana. I would like to pay special credit to Rose Chesterfield, who has instilled a love of the environment in all the students at Floraville Public School. It is little wonder that Floraville Public School is involved in Waterwatch and that the school has won the Lake Macquarie schools environment award and the New South Wales Gould League award for media and research for seven years.

Floraville Public School also teaches its students to love Australia. That is why the school decided to erect a flagpole to proudly fly the Australian flag. The school was delighted to learn that the Howard government had promised to pay for all schools to have a flagpole erected. But this delight turned to dismay as Floraville Public School tried to make the minister deliver on his promise. It is a rather interesting saga. The school contacted my office and we duly contacted the Minister for Education, Science and Training's office. We were fobbed off, but were eventually given an email address. Unfortunately, that email address was the wrong address. Then the school tried contacting the minister's office, emailing the office something like eight or nine times. There was no response from the minister.

By this stage the school was becoming very distressed because they had been so excited that the government had promised that it would deliver flagpoles to schools. I thought, `This just can't be right.' The Minister's office told the school to get into contact with the Department of Education and Training in Sydney. I believe that at one time the minister's office advised the school that it was a state government responsibility. This was quite contrary to what the minister had told this House and led the school to believe. On 27 July, a school representative visited my office yet again to tell me what had been happening and about the school's concern. I was told that the school was not going to give in; it was going to fight to get a flagpole for Floraville Public School. The school's determination paid off. Eventually, on 29 July, the school was given an application form to apply for funding.

The saga does not end there, because the school had to agree to all the accompanying conditions. They had to report the funding and installation of the pole, install a plaque saying that the Australian government had funded it and that it was a gift from the Australian government and invite Senator Tierney to attend a flag raising ceremony. As a secondary thought, they had to provide a tax invoice and a copy of the receipt. Floraville's flagpole was erected last weekend, and the Australian flag finally flew for the first time yesterday. But what a farce. This epitomises the Howard government's approach to education: politics, first; schools and education, second. Congratulations, Floraville, on your persistence. It paid dividends.

talk.start.para: —On 4 August I raised the issue of the after-hours general practitioner services which operate at hospitals in the Hunter. I also raised concerns that, whilst they were funded through to the end of June 2005, there was, as part of the contract negotiations, an evaluation process that was to be undertaken. With the delays in the evaluation, it would have meant that the after-hours GP service would have been wound up in March 2005 so that they could make the financial allowances for redundancy and termination pays. This is an excellent example of serving the community, and I fully support the after-hours GP service.

speech.para: In fact, as I stated in my speech in this House, since October 1999 almost 85,000 people have been seen as in-patients, some 67,000 people have obtained medical advice from the hotline and 800 home visits have been made by doctors. This is an outstanding service. To give you an idea of the benefits of supporting after-hours GP services based at hospitals, we have seen a reduction in triage categories 4 and 5 patients during clinic hours at emergency departments co-located with the new GPs after-hours clinics over the 12 months of service operation. That is not in my electorate. There was a 38.9 per cent reduction at Belmont Hospital and an 18.4 per cent reduction at the John Hunter Hospital, where people in my electorate go. No figures were provided for the Maitland Hospital. This arrangement provides high-quality care. As an example, some 47 per cent of patients were seen at or before their scheduled appointment times from Monday to Friday, 44 per cent on Saturdays and 37 per cent on Sundays. Some 92 per cent of all patients are seen within 30 minutes of their scheduled appointment time. There have been 213 commendations received during the first 12 months of service and, importantly, this service has always operated within its budget.

I appreciate the efforts of our Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, and the Prime Minister, who today signed off on extending the funding by 12 months, through to June 2006. We welcome this funding announcement because it means that the evaluation can continue without disrupting the service. I spoke today to Dr Chris Boyle, Chairman of the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice, and I said to him, as I said to Dr Arn Sprogis when this issue was first raised, that I would deliver, that the funding would be there and that the service would not have to shut down. It is a good day when we as representatives of our communities are able to achieve things on these projects.

Quality health care is important in my community, and I believe that quality research is also important to back up that health care. We have an outstanding facility in the Hunter called the Hunter Medical Research Institute. In a speech in support of the budget, I outlined that the federal government committed $5 million to help build the new Hunter Medical Research Institute. This is the only regionally based comprehensive health and medical research institute in Australia. It was established back in 1998 as a partnership between Hunter Health, the University of Newcastle and the Hunter community. It has more than 350 researchers, who work in the key areas of brain and mental health, cancer, cardiovascular health, health behaviour and public health, mothers and babies, vaccines, immunity, viruses and asthma.

Importantly, let us measure the institute's success. The institute is responsible for the discovery of a compound found in green leafy vegetables which stops cancer cell growth; the discovery of a placental clock that decides when a baby will be born; the establishment of a $12 million national centre of excellence in reproductive biotechnology; and the development of new vaccines for common infections.

A highlight in recent weeks was the efforts of Dr Darren Shafren. His amazing work is an example of what is happening in the Hunter region. He has been working on using the common cold virus as a treatment for melanoma. Lab results have shown success, with an injection of the virus destroying melanoma cells. The work is being described as a safe and effective treatment for malignant melanoma, breast and prostate cancers, and may have wider applications to ovarian, colorectal and lymphoid related cancers. It was announced last week that the University of Newcastle Research Associates, known as TUNRA, have signed a licensing agreement worth around $10 million with biotechnology company Psiron to develop anticancer treatments.

This is a new direction for the people of the Hunter; it is a new face, a new image. The problem is we have been waiting for the state Labor government in New South Wales to provide their $5 million in funding. I now call on that funding. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to speak on an issue that affects people in my electorate on a daily basis. Every morning and night, thousands of residents from Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh, Ballan and Gordon fight through the intersection at Deer Park on the Western Highway. Stuck with them in this bottleneck are millions of dollars worth of goods sitting on the backs of trucks waiting to be unloaded at their destinations in Melbourne or starting the long haul to Adelaide. This piece of road is not just some backstreet local road. This is a national highway between Adelaide and Melbourne, second only to the Hume Highway between Melbourne and Sydney for national haulage—and it is the Commonwealth government's responsibility to fund and maintain. It in one of the most dangerous pieces of road in Victoria, with over 139 accidents along the Western Highway between the Western Ring Road and Anthony's Cutting since July 2003.

speech.para: Commuters in my electorate have been waiting for years for this government to commit the full $294 million funding required for the construction of the Deer Park bypass. So on Monday, 7 June, when the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads unveiled the government's supposed nation-building AusLink, thousands of local commuters and I held our collective breaths for the announcement of full funding for the Deer Park bypass. But what did we get? We got $40 million for a $294 million project. On closer inspection, it was $40 million to start not next year but in 2007-08 and 2008-09, with no funding to finish the project. Like all announcements from this government, you need to look even closer and read the fine print. Buried in small writing was the fact that the government would seek further funding from the state government to complete the project. So on that Monday the Commonwealth government gave the Deer Park bypass $40 million to finish a $294 million project, with a request to the state government to help fund this national highway, a road that is the responsibility of the Commonwealth government to fund and maintain.

Quite rightly, the Victorian Minister for Transport said on the Wednesday that the state government could not assist the Commonwealth government to build a road that was 100 per cent a Commonwealth responsibility. In a backflip that would do any gymnast at the Athens Olympics proud, the minister for roads changed his mind yet again. By Friday he was saying that the Commonwealth would not seek funding from the state government for the Deer Park bypass but it would be subject to future Commonwealth budgets. So, between Monday and Friday, funding for the construction of the Deer Park bypass was a responsibility of the Commonwealth then of the Commonwealth and the states, and then, following an outcry on the Wednesday, responsibility was transferred back to the Commonwealth government, but with no commitment to fully fund it. Minister, you cannot start a project this size unless you know you have got the money to finish it.

During this period of uncertainty by the government we saw a display of complete arrogance from the Liberal Party. The previous member for Ballarat, Michael Ronaldson, now in the No. 1 spot on the Victorian Liberals Senate ticket—a position that guarantees his election to the Senate—labelled the reaction of the local Ballarat community to what was a disappointing announcement as `a dummy spit'. In a letter to the Courier on Wednesday, 9 June 2004 he accused those who were disappointed with the announcement of $40 million of having `a dummy spit' and said those who were objecting to the inadequate decision were `rank amateurs'. What an affront to the Western Highway Action Committee, who have been fighting for the Deer Park bypass for five years, to all of the local mayors who represent constituencies along that highway and to all the commuters from Ballarat, Bacchus Marsh, Gordon and Ballan.

There is only one party that will fully fund the Deer Park bypass—the $294 million required to complete this road—and that is the Labor Party. Only Labor recognise that this is a national highway, and as such we responded with a fully funded and costed commitment to build the Deer Park bypass, with construction to begin in the first year of a Latham Labor government. This is $294 million to build the whole project, with construction to begin in 2005-06. At this election, the choice will be clear. A vote for the Liberals will mean no Deer Park bypass, millions lost in the bottleneck and longer waits at the traffic lights. A vote for Labor means the Deer Park bypass will be built, with construction to start in 2005-06.

talk.start.para: —It is timely to be saying a few words this week on sport and sporting achievement. In three days' time the world's greatest sporting spectacle, the Olympics, will get underway in Athens. It is a time when we can become a bit parochial about our country as we reflect on the sacrifices and achievements of our sporting stars in doing their best for Australia on the sporting field. Worldwide sporting events provoke a certain patriotic fervour which is healthy for society and healthy for sport. Who can forget US swimmer Gary Hall Junior claiming that the USA team would smash the Australian team like guitars in a reference to the 4 x 100 metre freestyle event in Sydney? How sweet was the victory when the Australian team set a world record at the Sydney games to take the sprint relay crown off the Americans for the first time?

speech.para: At a local level, the Indi electorate has close links with the Olympic dream. Visitors to Wangaratta are greeted with a sign on the Ovens River highlighting our home-grown gold medallists Dean Woods in 1984 and Nick Morris in 1996; silver medallists Dean Woods in 1988 and Jamie Hoggan in 1984; and bronze medallist Dean Woods in 1988 and again in 1996. Beechworth's Emma George built up the profile of pole vaulting in Australia and remains a local hero. Benalla's Baden Cooke, recently in France, has arrived in Athens, and we wait with interest for the individual pursuit rounds that he will be competing in on 20 August. We wish him all the best.

However, in the north-east we do not have to wait for the Olympics to embrace sport. We have a very proud history of sporting achievement at a local level. Sporting activity has come to be a great unifier of local communities, be it through local football and netball clubs, soccer clubs, AusKick or, right across the electorate on a Sunday morning, through the thriving bicycle users groups or Wangaratta's Out and About walking and bike riding club. It is also a great symbol of volunteers and the hours that they put in, not only to raise funds but to organise events. The success and popularity of local sport in north-east Victoria owes a great deal to volunteers and the hundreds of hours they put in.

This sense of community is very special, particularly in country Australia and in north-east Victoria. All you need to do is go to a regular training session at the Wangaratta Rovers Oval or have a beer at the local pub with some of the players on a Saturday night after a win on the field to see the camaraderie, the mateship and the community links that our sporting teams foster. That is one of the great things about living in the north-east. This Saturday night I am heading to the Wangaratta Rovers' clubrooms for the annual club members' night where there will be a very special tribute to two of Rovers' favourite sons, Tony Pasquali and Matt Allen, along with further inductions to the club's hall of fame. Next week I will be participating in the Moyhu Primary School walking school bus to encourage our youngsters to be more physically active and to highlight the importance of physical activity. These types of events ensure that the notion of teamwork and sporting activity go hand in hand and arouse community involvement in the workings of our local school communities and recreational clubs. These are the sorts of events that bind us together.

This brings me to the Australian government's fight against childhood obesity. Building a Healthy, Active Australia is not just a catchy slogan for the government's program; it is a passionate call to arms for the whole community to get involved in a very serious problem. We should welcome the mandated levels of physical activity that will be entrenched in school curricula thanks to this government's reforms. These developments are a step in the right direction towards building healthier lives for our youngsters and stronger communities in which they will develop.

As we watch the successes of our Olympians in Athens, on the other side of the world, I hope there will be a renewed interest in sporting activity right across Australia. I know that in the local communities and hamlets of Indi not only our young children in primary and secondary schools but also adults are very engaged and involved in active participation in sport as well as in volunteering the hundreds of hours that are required to support local sporting events. My electorate has benefited from the community spirit, camaraderie and commitment to local events and it is an example for many other parts of Australia to follow. Hopefully, through the initiatives of this government to reduce childhood obesity, we will see many more of these activities fostered and developed in other parts of Australia.

talk.start.para: —At the forthcoming election there are many people living in Portsea and other parts of the Mornington Peninsula who will vote for the first, and perhaps only, time in their lives for the Labor candidate Simon Napthine. One of the reasons for that is this government's outrageous handling of the disposal of Point Nepean and, in particular, the intimidation and the `born to rule' attitude shown by the present member for Flinders and other members of the Liberal party who have been actively promoting commercial development for parts of Point Nepean. That `born to rule' mentality has included not one, not two, not three but four separate abusive phone calls from the member for Flinders to different members of the Mornington Peninsula community who have had the temerity to disagree with him about the future of Point Nepean. Bob Stewart of the Southern Peninsular Rescue Squad received a phone call from the member for Flinders, which is described in an article by Keith Platt in the Mail in July. It says:

quote.para: “... he accused me of being a traitor to the cause”.
“He told me I should have consulted him. Even after we pulled out—

speech.para: of the syndicate involved in the future of Point Nepean—

quote.para: ...he went on (over the phone) with one of these tantrums”.

speech.para: Mr Stewart is quoted as saying the member for Flinders `needs to grow up a bit'. In the same article a former Liberal party branch president related a phone call that `showed the acid side of Greg Hunt', the member for Flinders. The article says:

quote.para: “He is a verbal bully on the phone” said the man.
“I was not surprised he called but I felt as though I'd been bullied. You could hardly say he'd read “How to win Friends and Influence People”.
The man said Mr Hunt had wanted him to write to newspapers criticising the state government's plan to sell land at Devilbend reservoir, Moorooduc.
“But I saw that as diverting attention away from Point Nepean which is a much more significant piece of land” ...

speech.para: That was clearly a blatant attempt at manipulation by the member for Flinders. The article goes on to say:

“He accused me of having no integrity or honour and how dare I turn my back on his vision for Point Nepean”
Will Baillieu ... said Mr Hunt had used “pretty rich language” during a phone call 18 months or two years ago.
“He was aggressive and rude and told me that he expected to hear comments I had been making from “someone who is extremely rich”.
“It was quite an extraordinary phone call and I was quite stunned as I walked around the garden.

speech.para: It is not just the bullying phone calls; it is also the threat of litigation. Vicki Sullivan, an artist whose relatives were among the early settlers of Point Nepean, was shocked when she received a written demand for an apology from Mr David Stewart, a member of the consortium there. She was threatened and in fear of being forced to sell her house and pay court costs. She apologised. She also received a demand for an apology from the Point Nepean Trust chairman, Mr McKeon. Bob Stewart also received threat of a libel action. These threats of legal action are a classic way of attempting to stifle free speech and an unfortunate measure—a yardstick—of how the Liberal Party operates on the Mornington Peninsula.

The voters of Flinders deserve a member who will stand up for them, who will fight for them—not one who fights, bullies, browbeats and intimidates them. I am sure that many people on the Mornington Peninsula will be keen to support Simon Napthine, the Labor candidate. They know that the deed of arrangement which the government has recently announced concerning Point Nepean does not indicate that Point Nepean will be handed over as national park. Indeed, it suggests that their trust will require a 75 per cent vote from the trust in order that the land be handed over as national park. A Labor government will hand Point Nepean over to the Victorian government to be a national park for all Victorians for all time.

subdebateinfo.title: Kingsford Smith Electorate: Port Botany Expansion

talk.start.para: —As the House may be aware, there is a potential environmental catastrophe facing the electorate of Kingsford Smith in southern Sydney through the New South Wales Labor government's plan to redevelop the Port Botany facility. Mr Garrett, your beds are burning. At the same time that locals in the seat of Kingsford Smith are fighting airport and container terminal expansions, ballooning traffic problems, carcinogenic and heavy metal poisoning and the biggest environmental threat to Botany Bay in its history, Mr Garrett is happily toeing the Labor Party line and keeping his real views to himself.

speech.para: What has been fascinating to watch since Mr Garrett's imposed candidacy for the safe Labor seat of Kingsford Smith has been his complete and utter silence on any issue regarding Kingsford Smith and Port Botany. It might interest the House to note that the Port Botany stevedoring facility is located in the heart of the erstwhile environmental activist turned Labor's star candidate's electorate, but it is left to the Liberal member from an adjoining seat to stand up for the environment—namely, me. Mr Garrett, do you serve the boys of Sussex Street or do you aspire to serve the people of Kingsford Smith? It is not that Mr Garrett is unaware of the massive problems with the port expansion. When President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, he was among the most vocal critics of the expansion plans.

That is not to say that Mr Garrett has been idle—far from it. Last Wednesday's article in the Daily Telegraph sheds some light as to where Mr Garrett has been fighting the good fight; titled `Garrett fighting on the wrong home front', it would appear that the soon to be member for Kingsford Smith has been fighting to stop the development of 600 public housing homes in Mittagong, which unfortunately would ruin the vista from his $2.5 million home in the Southern Highlands. It is time Mr Garrett came clean. Either he believes in protecting the environment or he does not. If he does, it is time for him to follow his own advice, time for Mr Garrett to say fair's fair, to pay the rent, to pay his share. Perhaps more fittingly, it is fine for Mr Garrett to think globally but, in the view of the residents of Kingsford Smith, it is well past the time for him to act locally.

The New South Wales Labor government has proposed, through the Sydney Ports Corporation, to expand the Port Botany container facility, tripling the number of containers handled per year from one million to three million. The proposal is estimated to cost New South Wales residents $580 million. The ramifications of the proposal to expand the Port Botany facility has given southern Sydney residents real cause for concern. It has the potential to significantly damage and further degrade the fragile marine environment of Botany Bay, choke the already stressed roads and rail transport corridors and add to the vulnerability of Port Botany as a potential terror target. I understand the port expansion as proposed by the New South Wales government will involve the reclamation of 60 hectares of the bay, which will make way for six additional shipping berths. This will result in more than 7.5 million cubic metres of sand being dredged from the floor of Botany Bay.

The northern side of Botany Bay around the container terminus has long been used as a site for heavy industry and commercial uses. This has meant that the ground waters beneath the bay and adjacent to the site of the proposed expansion have become heavily contaminated with pollutants. The ground water beneath the bay is also heavily contaminated with heavy metals and other particulate pollution. The dredging of the bay floor and reclamation of the equivalent of 120 football fields of the bay for the new terminal will release a toxic plume of heavy metals and pollutants. Computer and wave modelling shows that this toxic plume would travel south across the bay and endanger the Towra Point Nature Reserve, an area that is of such environmental worth that it was listed for protection under Ramsar treaty in the 1980s. It will completely encircle and irretrievably damage the Penrhyn Estuary, which was the last wading habitat on the northern side of the bay. Towra Point is home to over 95 per cent of the remaining salt marshes and more than 50 per cent of the remaining mangrove communities in the Sydney basin.

What we are saying is that the New South Wales government needs to look at alternatives. Both Newcastle and Port Kembla have indicated they would be more than happy to accommodate the additional port facilities, bringing as they would much-needed employment opportunities into these communities. Under the government's Auslink white paper the New South Wales government would be able to apply for a share of $1.8 billion to build the rail infrastructure that would be required to service these ports. We are concerned about those seats that adjoin Botany Bay and we are calling on Peter Garrett, the star Labor candidate, to stand up for his environmental credentials and condemn this proposal for Botany Bay. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 June 2004:

quote.para: In respect of the decision to retire the F111's, was the Defence Science and Technology Organisation asked to provide detailed advice to the Government; if not, why not; if so, what were the areas covered and what was the date of the advice.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
Fran Bailey
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The decision to retire the F-111 was taken by the Government on the basis of advice from Defence. This advice was developed with regard to many factors, including the capability, supportability and cost of the aircraft, and was sourced from a range of specialist areas within Defence, including the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO).

In relation to the areas covered, DSTO's role in Defence is to support decision-making concerning in-service Australian Defence Force aircraft. This advice includes science and technology advice on aircraft life assessment and life extension, and to advise on capability and capability upgrade options. The life assessment activity provides three important outcomes, these are:

answer.para: it supports technical airworthiness;
it provides a basis for planning and budgeting support activities, such as inspections repairs or replacements, and
it provides the Government with information to base decisions on whether and when to upgrade or replace the capability.
